googleSheetVaApiDataRow.earlyVotingNotes: Hawaii is all vote by mail as of 2020, but Voter Service Centers will be open 10 business days prior to and through Election Day for accessible voting, in-person voting, and same-day registration. A list of locations and hours will be posted on  https://elections.hawaii.gov.
googleSheetVaApiDataRow.vbmNotes: Entirely VBM starting in 2020. No need to submit a separate VBM Application, as all ballots will be mailed ~3 weeks before each election to address where registered to vote. Can submit a One-Time Absentee Application to indicate an alternate delivery address if needed. One-time Absentee requests may be made either for specific elections or one election cycle.
googleSheetVaApiDataRow.idRequirementsSdr: Voters must provide ID to prove their name, date of birth, residence address and mailing address. Bring your Hawaii driver's license or state ID card with you. If you don't have one, bring ONE photo ID that shows your name, and ONE document that shows your name and current address.  Acceptable documents include a utility bill, bank statement, paycheck, residential lease, or any government document that shows your name and address.
googleSheetVaApiDataRow.registrationNvrfBox6: Provide your Hawaii driver’s license or State identification number.  If you do not have either number, provide the last 4 digits of your social security number. If you do not have any of these numbers, please write NONE on the form.
googleSheetVaApiDataRow.vbmAbsenteeBallotRules:
* All Hawaii elections are vote-by-mail.  
* You can still request a one-time absentee ballot if you will be temporarily out of town during a specific election.
googleSheetVaApiDataRow.registrationNvrfSubmissionAddress:
Office of Elections  
State of Hawaii  
802 Lehua Avenue  
Pearl City, HI 96782
googleSheetVaApiDataRow.idRequirementsInPersonVoting: Hawaii voters do not need to show ID.
googleSheetVaApiDataRow.vbmWarnings: The Local Election Office will compare your signature on your voted ballot to the one on your driver’s license.  If the signatures don't match, your ballot might be rejected.  Please sign carefully.
googleSheetVaApiDataRow.year2020LegalChanges: As of January 2020, Hawaii will hold all elections by mail. Registered voters will automatically receive a mail-in ballot approximately 18 days before the election. There will be no traditional polling places. Instead there will be "voter service centers" that open 10 business days prior to Election Day; voters can return their ballots to these centers if they so choose.
googleSheetVaApiDataRow.vbmApplicationDirections:
* All Hawaii elections are held by mail.  This means that Hawaii will automatically send a mail-in ballot to every registered voter for the November 3, 2020 election.  
* If you need to update your mailing address **permanently**, [register to vote again](http://www.voteamerica.com/register-to-vote/) using your new mailing address. 
* If you need to update your mailing address **temporarily** -- because you will be out of town for the November 3, 2020 election --  [request a one-time absentee ballot](http://www.voteamerica.com/absentee-ballot/).
googleSheetVaApiDataRow.registrationNvrfBox7: You do not need to register with a pollitical party.
googleSheetVaApiDataRow.idRequirementsOvr: You will need a Hawaii ID and a Social Security number to use Hawaii's online voter registration system. If you do not have a Hawaii ID, you can still register to vote by mail.
googleSheetVaApiDataRow.idRequirementsVbm: Hawaii voters do not need to provide ID when voting by mail.
googleSheetVaApiDataRow.registrationRules:
To register in Hawaii you must:

  * be a citizen of the United States
  * be a resident of the State of Hawaii
  * be at least 16 years old (you must be 18 years old by Election Day in order to vote)
  * not be incarcerated for a felony conviction
  * not be adjudicated by a court as non compos mentis
